review_title: Good students but the university is rather stingy
job_title: Postdoctoral Teaching Fellow in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Students are smart and motivated. It is a pleasure to teach them. You have a lot of autonomy when teaching classes (nobody controls what you do; however, nobody is checking on you either... - as a postdoctoral fellow, you often feel like you are on your own).
cons: The university pays $65,000 annually, while the MINIMUM salary for exempt employees in California (in 2023) is $64,480. This means, that a person with a Ph.D. and several years of teaching and research experience will be just 25 cents above the minimum hourly wage ($520÷2080, assuming there are 2080 work hours per year). Another problem is that the contracts are usually just for one year and you don't get confirmation that they will be renewed till the last month or week of your employment (actually, last year I got a new contract on the very last day of my employment). This creates unnecessary stress. This could be easily addressed by giving people contracts earlier (till the very last moment I was uncertain whether I would work next month or not).

review_title: Great Place & People to Work With, But Not Enough Pay
job_title: Digital Imaging Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I love the people I've worked with over the years. We have great benefits, more paid time off than most other places.
cons: They don't adjust for inflation. I cant work overtime. I cant even technically work 40 hour /week, it has to be right under for some reason (39 hours tops). They don't give bonuses and their "raises" are meaningless when not adjusting for inflation and are of less value percentage wise than the inflation percentage, which technically means you're actually getting a pay cut. I've brought this up to a Dean who did try to actually help get the whole department increased wages, but her proposal got shut down. Priorities with funding in this university are for the sports department and teams. We can hire on a new football coach, fly him over, buy his multimillion dollar home, give him full access year round to a private jet and pay him a salary of $10 million, but increased pay for the Library staff? Forget it. All of this said does not mean this is across the entire University, but as far as I know, this applies to my department at the USC Libraries (specifically the Digital Library)

review_title: It was great... until it wasn't
job_title: Graphic Designer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits are good, the work can be rewarding (when it's there), and the people on my team are great to work with/alongside
cons: After two years of being on a team of designers that did a lot of great work, work that was highly reviewed by our superiors and THEIR superiors as well, I and my fellow designers were suddenly told that we'd be reduced from full-time employees to part-time, making less than half of what we made before the change. USC's rationale behind this decision was that they "didn't have enough money to keep us all on full time" and had decided to outsource half our work to a company overseas that would do it for cheap. Again: myself and my fellow designers did nothing wrong, and had been told several times how much we and the level of our work were/was appreciated... And yet we promptly were told that we either accept a reduced position with reduced salary or we quit altogether. I don't for a second believe the rationale given for the change: that USC, of all places/institutions/universities, was low on money. I and the others affected 110% do NOT believe that excuse. What I and my coworkers DO believe is that USC saw an opportunity to outsource jobs we'd worked hard at and were dedicated to doing well just to save a buck. Just to save a salary or two or three and send our jobs elsewhere rather than look after their hardworking employees or reflect, in kind, the dedication and loyalty we had given them.

review_title: Nice people but university that tries to exploit you
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar Fellow in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good research opportunities. Nice people to work with. Smart and motivated students to teach.
cons: Postdoctoral Scholar - Teaching Fellows have relatively high teaching load (3 classes per year, the same as assistant professors) but are paid about 40% less. Assistant professor gets about $105k (with annual increases of about 3-5%) + benefits (e.g., retirement plan matching, short but paid maternity leave, etc.). Postdocs with the same teaching load get $65k, no annual increases, no benefits, unpaid maternity or family leave, no retirement plan matching. As a postdoc, you are neither treated as a staff nor faculty - postdoc is a separate cathegory. You still must perform some duties of the faculty (you can be asked to be on a committee, to supervise a senior project, to supply questions to qualifying exams) but you have neither benefits of being a faculty nor job stability of those. Finally, the salary. The minimum wage for except workers in LA county in 2022 is $62,400 per year. USC pays you just $65,000 per year (and it doesn't even give you some basic things like 5% retirement plan matching, something that you would get in almost any other job). To add insult to the injury, you are treated as a dispensable person. While my research colleagues and local (departmental) staff were nice, some encounters with the central administration were disheartening.

job_title: Associate Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good intellectual environment, good science, opportunities for collaboration, nice weather.
cons: I have been at USC for over 10 years and can attest that the place is systematically corrupt. The administration is very facetious and there are a lot of unscrupulous, sinister figures at the top. There are some outstanding researchers, but there is also a lot of dead wood. The place is also a masters diploma mill (anyone with a pulse gets a degree if they can pay). The 18 schools within the university compete against each other for student tuition revenue, which stifles collaboration and gives the place a siloed atmosphere. The bureaucracy is very slow and inefficient. This is mostly due to the failure of the administration to hire more staff in positions that are actually needed and to their propensity to hire other people in positions that make the university look good on paper. The vision of the administration is politically ideological, opportunistic, and in constant change according to the political climate of the day. This is a very greedy university and the goals are very budget-driven. Recent scandals have prompted some changes at the top, but a major remaining problem is that the board of trustees and the president have decided long ago to run the place like a corporation. If you are a very high profile faculty member with tenure, you are held to a different standard because you can get away with a lot.

job_title: Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Vibrant city, affiliation with this well known institution can help open other doors. Lovely campus with many social opportunities. Citywide events make for interesting collaborations. Alumni opportunities for networking are vast. Exposure to world class thought leaders throughout L.A.
cons: Long-term negative impact of relentless scandals impacts budgets at every level, creating a difficult under-funded work environment. Much of leadership throughout campus and at highest levels lacking transparent strategic planning and intentional commitment to employee development and wellness (i.e. Dental School, School of Social Work, Keck) despite stating and producing documents/reports of empathic stance to build positive culture and diverse faculty and staff. The university-wide push to develop more cash-infusing graduate programs and certifications in effort to increase revenue is harming intellectual depth and reputation, and taking away from undergraduate resources. Athletic Department financial problems mean immediate decreased budgets for all academic programs. Reliance on technology contract companies such as 2U has markedly decreased quality of classroom instruction, especially in virtual and online offerings. Imminent threats of layoffs and restructuring continually present creating tense and stressful work environment with low morale. Interdisciplinary opportunities are increasingly rare as programs and initiatives are typically siloed. The university is in trouble in many areas and it will take years to recover. Maybe joining the PAC12 will be the needed Hail Mary.

review_title: Good place to start or to retire
job_title: Project Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent place to start (or to retire), you can learn a lot especially that the environment is stress free and there is no pressure on employees . Strong team culture, mission, vision, and values are strongly shared for the most of it. If you start here and are able learn from all the seniors around you, you can get anywhere. Medical, dental, and vision insurance are industry average. 401K is above industry average and you get tuition as well which is an excellent benefit.
cons: Depending on where you work, the culture and environment might be very different. In general, there is a strong hierarchy in terms of management with mostly a “no open door” policy. Issues are discussed but never resolved, sometimes faced with denial because nobody wants to take responsibility. Professional and career improvement is almost non existent, or you have to wait many many years. Compensation is below industry average, and I believe the reason is the stress free environment and the bureaucracy among departments. No one has a real sense of urgency because roles and responsibilities are not well defined, so nobody truly wants to take ownership. It is still worth getting a job there and taking as much experience as you can, it is valuable.

Leadership and culture is toxic from top to bottom. From numerous scandals at the highest levels of the organization to petty, retaliatory practices from middle management, and a broken HR reporting system - USC has a troubling culture that taints the work environment. 

There is a lot of bureaucracy mired in traditional academic/research practices - meaning you will have to navigate fragile egos and a system of favors in order to get things done both within your department and inter-departmentally.

All of that and you will be paid lower in your field while living in a very expensive city. 

Employees are charged for parking on University grounds or have to pay to park nearby in private lots. Paid parking is reserved for senior management and faculty.

review_title: Roski Galen Intermedia Lab, Work-study Lab Tech
job_title: Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-The Galen Lab is a really cool space where you can meet a lot of neat creative people.
-The location is on campus and your hours are flexible, which makes it easy to fit into campus life and school life.
-It's really wonderful to be able to help other students and get comfortable with really useful and important creative tools.
-When there isn't much going on in the lab (it depends on the day and time and whether there's an assignment due soon for students in one of the Roski classes that use the lab often), it's pretty calm. Sometimes you can even work on homework or other projects without being interrupted for fairly long periods.
-The pay isn't super high or anything, but it's good side income for a college student trying to make enough to cover food and a bit of pocket money.
-A really nice job for people who like to learn, assist others, and be part of a creative makerspace. Helps build skills from both a technology angle and a customer service angle.
cons:
-When the lab is hectic, it's really hectic and can get a bit overwhelming to manage, even when you're working a shift with your supervisor, the resident lab expert.
-It's a work-study job, so you need to be eligible for work-study to get it.
-Someone in a wheelchair most likely could not access the Galen Lab.
-The supervisor isn't exactly a bad person but isn't the most patient person ever. He can often be pretty rude to both students using the lab and occasionally even the work-studies working under him, and can be very insensitive towards other people in general.... The fact that he is overworked and not given enough resources for the lab by the school worsens this. If you're really sensitive you'll need to be careful of this.
-There isn't a working water fountain in the building the lab is part of, so if you don't bring enough of your own water to stay hydrated, you're forced to either buy something bottled from a nearby vending machine, stay parched for a while, run to the other Roski building, or jog up to a nearby science lecture hall lobby if you can't access the other Roski building. Also, it can be hard to find the time to do that when you're the only one manning the lab and it's busy.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: USC has a beautiful campus and is a prestigious institution to work at. The students are really smart and competitive. Benefits and pay, for this type of role, are also nationally competitive (can't do much better, unfortunately). The health insurance is top tier (Aetna PPO, minimal copays). The culture can be really great depending on the department you work for.
cons: Where to start... Well, there is no guarantee on summer pay (and in the future this is looking like there'll be no guarantee on annual stipend renewal either). I got unlucky and had to pull teeth with my advisor to provide (at times no, at times half, and one lucky time full) summer funding. There is seemingly no push for faculty to bring in grant money. In my department, we had about 2-3 professors with funding, leaving nearly all PhD students to fend for themselves during the summers. Overall, the campus culture is every (wo)man for themselves, and it's extremely hard to build relationships with staff or faculty. I blame this on each department and office being so cramped up into the tiniest of spaces and often also broken up across different buildings relatively far from each other. Almost everyone who worked in my department felt lonely. Some thrived in that but most just put up with it. In 5 years, there was one admin position that went through 4 different people. People just kept leaving. If you're a PhD candidate, most people still treat you like an undergrad. As a TA, I got only a few hours of petagogic training before I embarked on a 5+ year journey teaching every semester. There was no accountability and no interest for our work as TAs. All TAs for all classes shared 1 office with 4 desks, rotating through. A lot of people work remotely to compensate for a miserable (amount of) space they're given on campus. Really, I spent most of my time unable to enjoy work and intellectual freedom and teaching here. I expected a very different experience off the sales pitch I got before applying. USC is not the private school environment that puts the student first. It really feels more like UCLA with pretty classrooms. If you want to build real relationships with students, I recommend going anywhere else at this point. I felt unable to give back the experience I had in undergrad because every effort felt like throwing time into a void. No one cared either way, not students, not faculty, not admins.

job_title: MSEE Student, PhD Graduate Student in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Viterbi is an excellent Engineering school with talented professors who conduct relevant and interesting research. The Earth Sciences Department is full of good folks and is generous with travel grants. For TA/RA's: Decent pay (for a grad stipend); subsidized public transit (bus and train); acceptable gym; access to museums and stadiums near campus; 3 train-stops at campus.
cons: Health coverage is acceptable but confusing. Different students are referred to different doctors who perform the same services for different rates. Campus is a frying pan in a hot, polluted, arid city. More trees would make walking around campus feel less like navigating a molten parking lot. The area around campus is somewhat lacking for beauty and functionality. Much of that is just the way LA is designed to (not) work, though. Car traffic around campus is usually bad and cars drive much too fast in areas with heavy pedestrian traffic. Many undergrads appear to take little interest in class. Many other undergrads seem to lack significant academic talent. The graduate programs here > undergraduate programs, in my opinion.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
It's a relaxed atmosphere--which has it's downside, too, actually.
It is a fairly low stress environment to work in.
The benefits package is great. 2:1 match on retirement fund.
There are some great people at USC.
Being around the college environment keeps you fresh.
cons:
The IT of the University is in shambles. Broken processes; legacy systems; system logic not being documented, only residing in a single person's mind. etc. 
Management is really hit or miss. There are some great, wise, patient, intelligent leaders, while others seem completely clueless about how to run a profitable organization. 
Efficiency is not a value here. Being slow, patient, and understanding is the M.O. of the University folks. Many of the upper management types seem disconnected from reality. Head in the clouds. Wouldn't last a second outside of a University environment.
On the IT side, there are contractors. And these contractors take advantage of the University's patience and deep pockets. Again, feeding in to the overall lack of efficiency at the University.

job_title: Statistics Tutor/Teacher Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: This is a great summer job opportunity for people who are interested in the field of education. You get the ability to be very involved in the summer academic life of 50-60 high school students that are low-income minority students from the area. The program is composed of students who have a passion for higher education and want to strive for success after they complete high school. You also get to participate on a large portion of their field trips and have great bonding experiences with the students throughout the summer program.
cons: The work schedule was a bit inconvenient because it was divided into two work shifts. In the morning, you would attend the math/statistics courses that you are assigned to for the summer and work alongside the teacher to help manage the class. In the afternoon, you had to come back to campus to lead a study/review session with the students. In this afternoon portion, you would review the material that was covered earlier in the morning and then proceed to help the students with their homework and check them off. If you plan to hold a second summer job, it might be difficult to arrange a working schedule that will not interfere with these two divided work shifts.

review_title: Great environment, great benefits - Fight On!
job_title: Systems Programmer in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Overall, the day-to-day experience of working at USC is absolutely fantastic.  The campus is beautiful, self-enclosed, not too big and not too small, and moments away from downtown LA and Hollywood.  It has a sizable student body of 17,000 undergraduate and 17,000 graduate students.  School spirit is high and the people (both students and staff) are open and easygoing.  It is truly the quintessential college experience.

There are lots of things to do on campus, and I personally have enjoyed some of the staff benefits such as using the USC libraries, track and workout facilities.  I am also taking advantage of the tuition assistance program by getting a masters degree.  The University retirement program is also very generous.
cons: Although benefits are great, the actual salary of an average USC staff member is probably lower than the industry average.  Also, with limited land space, many departments have been forced to move off-campus to buildings in industrial areas of downtown Los Angeles.  And although school spirit may be high, co-operation between the different University departments is low.  Politics play a large role in the social makeup of the University staff.

job_title: Technical Staff in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I had a fantastic experience working in the Department of Performance Venue (now called Trojan Event Services) where we were encouraged to learn as we worked. As student employees, we were given technical training and opportunities that paralleled a job requiring much more experience than we had. I started with no technical theater background and was taught from the ground up. We worked on events with Elton John, Vampire Weekend, TEDxUSC, and Presidents Clinton and Bush among many others. Students ran every show as stage managers, production managers, house managers, and lead audio and lighting techs.
cons: Unfortunately, the bureaucracy that is USC failed to keep its finances and enforced terrible changes on our department. Every person in the org chart from my boss to the Provost of the University have left in the last two years (and I am not missing a single individual) mostly due to the incompetence of their superiors, excluding maybe the people in the top few rungs. In the meantime, our full-time staffing has been reduced to 10% of its original size. Staffing for events was dangerously low and maintenance was not dealt with for two years. Policies were put in place that hindered our work without consultation. Long overdue and promised raises have yet to be distributed. The new administration has no knowledge or interest in what we do in tech and the students and full-time employees have faced terrible payroll and administrative problems that are waived off by the administration. There was finally one technical hire and he is promising, but he still reports to irresponsible administration. Here's hoping things change for the better under his direction for the sake of the students and the University.

review_title: Full of Talent - Currently going through an identity crisis
job_title: in Marina del Rey, CA
pros:
Very smart and talented people who are also very nice in most groups.
In most group your Project leader or Division director will shield you from top level politics.
A variety of projects.
Good collaboration between groups.
Flexible work hours, co-operative supervisors.
cons:
Lots of overhead for tech support, facilities and university's cut.
Top level management seems to be wasting money in trying to find new sources of funding. Hired many expensive people who have done little to justify their salaries.
Top level management bureaucratic, erratic, money-minded while almost all the people who do the actual work are there to do research.
Top level management recently attempted to change the culture of the place through an iron fist. It backfired spectacularly, made lots of very talented people unhappy and now they seem to be in damage control mode.
Complaints reached the School of Engineering (parent of ISI), they seem to be interested in soothing the researchers but not really interested in making the top level management change their policies.
It will be interesting to see how ISI emerges out of this identity crisis.

review_title: Graduate Student - CAD designer at USC Facilities Management Services (FMS)
job_title: CAD Designer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: It's a great opportunity for a student of Architecture or Engineering to get in hand with US building codes, building surveys, documenting and reporting files. As a student you can have a more flexible work schedule defined by you and your supervisor, since school and classes are your first priority. It's a relaxed working environment, where you can perform well and be productive. The salary is flat rate for most if not for all students working at FMS. A bus runs from USC campus to the office which makes it easy for student to commute if they don't have a bike or they prefer to avoid walking, especially during summer time. Sometimes the work may become monotonic, but feel comfortable and confident to ask for a different type project, to explore other skills. In my opinion they like students who want to learn more, increase their experiences and knowledge. It was a very good experience for me and I would recommend it to other students as well.
cons: The only disadvantage I had to face was the computer equipment, they were not all very well performing at that time, which made the work pace slower. From what I've heard though they've upgraded them all few months ago, therefore it shouldn't be any similar issue now.
